There is no bundled component for doing so, but it should be easy to 
write, either in Java or one of the scripting languages Heritrix supports.

You don't mention which version you're using, so I'll assume Heritrix 
3.0.0+ ("H3").

Every processor may optionally have its own DecideRule (or more 
usefully, set of rules via something like DecideRuleSequence), called 
'shouldProcessRule'. If changed from the default (an always-ACCEPT 
rule), and the rule returns REJECT, the Processor's normal activity will 
be skipped.

Thus, adding rules to whatever Processor is doing your content-writing 
such that they REJECT uninteresting content will have the desired effect.

Rules are passed the CrawlURI instance, which for any successful fetch 
includes ways to access the retrieved content as either an InputStream 
or a CharSequence. Rules may be written in Java or via the 
ScriptedDecideRule class, supplied with their behavior by any JSR-223 
scripting engine. Javascript (aka ECMAScript), Beanshell, and Groovy 
should always be available as options in our standard distribution; 
adding JRuby or Jython or Clojure shouldn't be hard.

- Gordon @ IA
